At the time of his death Harriman controlled the [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]], the [[Southern Pacific Railroad|Southern Pacific]], the [[St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad|Saint Joseph and Grand Island]], the [[Illinois Central Railroad|Illinois Central]], the [[Central of Georgia Railroad|Central of Georgia]], the [[Pacific Mail Steamship Company]], and the [[Wells Fargo|Wells Fargo Express Company]]. Estimates of his estate ranged from US$200 million to US$600 million. It was left entirely to his wife.
At the time of his death Harriman controlled the [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]], the [[Southern Pacific Railroad|Southern Pacific]], the [[St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad|Saint Joseph and Grand Island]], the [[Illinois Central Railroad|Illinois Central]], the [[Central of Georgia Railroad|Central of Georgia]], the [[Pacific Mail Steamship Company]], and the [[Wells Fargo|Wells Fargo Express Company]]. Estimates of his estate ranged from US$200 million to US$600 million. It was left entirely to his wife.

===The Harriman Alaska Expedition===
  +
{{main|Harriman Alaska Expedition}}
  +
In 1899, Harriman financed and accompanied a scientific expedition to catalog the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] of the [[Alaska]] coastline from its lush southern panhandle to [[Prince William Sound]]. Among the scholars who joined him were [[John Burroughs]], [[John Muir]], [[George Bird Grinnell]], [[Louis Agassiz Fuertes]], [[Edward Curtis]], [[Trevor Kincaid]], [[Albert Fisher]], [[Robert Ridgway]], [[Charles Keeler]], [[Frederick Coville]], [[Frederick Samuel Dellenbaugh|Frederick Dellenbaugh]], [[William Emerson Ritter]] and [[Clinton Hart Merriam]]. They made the trip on a luxuriously refitted {{convert|250|ft|m|adj=on}} steamer called the "George W. Elder."
